info.game_comments:
2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 2, game 16.

(Jimmy: We'll bring you great moments in sports history--ESPN style--today on Jeopardy!)
(Sarah, Jimmy & Cheryl: [To the tune of the ESPN theme] Ta-da-da, ta-da-da!)

(1, 1).clue: The Latins called Attila Flagellum Dei, which means this

(2, 1).clue: Jeff Probst knows this group hit the top spot in 1982 with "Eye Of The Tiger"

(4, 1).clue: Evolution has given the giant panda this many digits on each hand, 2 more than most Disney characters

(5, 1).clue: Nurses Week begins on May 6th & ends May 12th--appropriately, this woman's birthday

(6, 1).clue: It occupies almost all of the British Isles except for the Republic of Ireland

(1, 2).clue: In 451 Attila conquered, then abandoned, this town in Gaul where 961 years later a certain "maid" was born

(2, 2).clue: They had 3 No. 1s, including "Blame It On The Rain"; too bad they never actually sang on any of them

(4, 2).clue: Markings on teeth from a Ukraine site led anthropologists to believe humans first rode these 6,000 years ago

(5, 2).clue: On Friendship Day, buy your bud a stuffed animal of this honey lover, the U.N.'s Friendship Ambassador

(6, 2).clue: From the Latin for "the womb", it's where the embryo is nourished

(1, 3).clue: In 441 Attila's forces razed Singidunum, on whose site this capital of Serbia & Montenegro was built

(2, 3).clue: "Might As Well Face It", the video for this 1986 Robert Palmer hit was famed for its zombie-liked backup band of models

(4, 3).clue: In a prophecy, Isaiah says a cow's calf will lie down with this animal's cub

(5, 3).clue: This month was chosen for Grandparents Day to signify the autumn of life

(6, 3).clue: In 1851 the National Era began publishing installments of this Stowe work

(1, 4).clue: At its peak, Attila the Hun's empire ranged from the Rhine River eastward to the Ural River & this sea

(2, 4).clue: Christopher Cross hit No. 1 in 1981 with a song from this movie; it was the best that he could do

(3, 4).clue: Produces more theatrical feature films every year than any other country

(4, 4).clue: Unlike the common ones of these insects found in your kitchen, the Madagascan one may hiss when disturbed

(5, 4).clue: Kiss-up alert: National Boss Day falls in this same month that clocks are set back an hour

(6, 4).clue: He was Major League Baseball Commissioner from 1984 to 1989

(1, 5).clue: Attila appears under the name Etzel in this 13th c. German epic poem later adapted into a Wagner work
(1, 5).correct response: Das Nibelungenlied (or The Ring of the Nibelung)

(2, 5).clue: Staff Sergeant Barry Sadler sang "The Ballad Of" these men in 1966 but a follow-up single, "The A-Team", fizzled

(3, 5).clue: Despite its larger resources, Brazil lost an 1820s war with Argentina that resulted in this new country between them

(4, 5).clue: The largest animal ever to fly, the quetzalcoatlus was one of these whose 9-letter name means "wing lizard"

(5, 5).clue: In 1939 this publisher, editor & politician gave Citizenship Day prominence through his newspapers

(6, 5).clue: Soldiers awarded the medal of honor are said to have exhibited this kind of "valor"

(1, 1).clue: The venture aims to preseve our literary heritage; No. 1 in the series contains this author's "Omoo", "Typee" & "Mardi"

(2, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports.)  December 31st, 1967:On the frozen tundra of Lambeau field, Bart Starr sneaks the winning touchdown  to lead this team over Dallas, 21-17

(3, 1).clue: In 1610, while serving as court mathematician for the Grand Duke of Tuscany, he first observed the rings of Saturn

(4, 1).clue: Peter Coyote was in "E.T.", this deputy defense secretary was nominated to head the World Bank

(5, 1).clue: Henry Fuseli's painting of this Shakespeare character might give the Louvre-goer a fright

(6, 1).clue: Hollywood's superficial glamour gave it this nickname

(1, 2).clue: David Halberstam & Stanley Karnow are represented in a collection of reportage of this event

(2, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports.) March 2, 1962, the NBA:It's slamtastic as his dipper dunk brings him to 100 points on the night

(3, 2).clue: He developed the 3rd of his laws of planetary motion while serving as provincial mathematician in Linz, Austria

(4, 2).clue: Of people named this, it wasn't Dean or Bessie but Ian who led Rhodesia

(5, 2).clue: He painted the work known around the Louvre as "La Joconde"

(6, 2).clue: Medical condition of persistent noise in the ear

(1, 3).clue: He gets 7 volumes, including "The Gilded Age and Later Novels"

(2, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports.)  June 19, 1946:This heavyweight had warned Billy Conn "He can run but he can't hide"; eighth round, ooh!ouch! thhh--the running ceases

(3, 3).clue: In his 1573 work "De Nova Stella", this Dane wrote down his observation of his newly discovered star

(4, 3).clue: Pat Robertson's a minister; this man chairs the Senate Intelligence Committee

(5, 3).clue: Title of the Watteau work seen here, it's the French version of the Commedia dell'arte's Pedrolino

(6, 3).clue: A positive photograph made on a plate of sensitized metal

(1, 4).clue: "The Royal Family" & "You Can't Take It WIth You" are in a volume of plays credited to this man "& Co."

(2, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports.)  February 22, 1959:So you say you can't go 135 mph in an Oldsmobile?  Lee Petty did, winning the first running of this in Florida

(3, 4).clue: As assistant to her planet discoverer brother, she herself discovered 8 comets

(4, 4).clue: In 2003 Ernie Eves was premier of Ontario; in 1915 this Illinois native chaired the Intl. Congress of Women

(5, 4).clue: This man transferred 5,000 civil servants out of the Louvre & inaugurated the resulting new art wing in 1993

(6, 4).clue: This man's work, "Christ at the Sea of Galilee", is seen here

(1, 5).clue: Most of the series is collections, but this 1925 Dreiser novel has its own 972-page volume

(2, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports.)  1912:Gustav V says, "Sir, you are the greatest athlete in the world"; His reply--"Thanks, King"

(3, 5).clue: In the 1850s this American stargazer visited the Vatican Observatory, which would only admit her by day

(4, 5).clue: One was a bandleader who worked with Gershwin; one joined the Supreme Court in 1970

(5, 5).clue: Since the 1600s the Louvre has owned the work seen here by Claude Gellée, also known as this, for his region of birth

(6, 5).clue: Coastal Cornish village said to be the birthplace of King Arthur

(0, 0).clue: Its original meaning was a resident of a certain wealthy city; now it means one who indulges in luxury
